1.content:
It was just after 7:00 in the morning, I’d been lying awake in bed for almost the last 90 minutes. Rolling over in bed, I looked over the dozing body of my girlfriend Amber. Last night had been our 5-month anniversary, so we celebrated by enjoying a romantic dinner followed by passion-filled evening in bed.

I’d been having these feelings of uncertainty lately where my life didn’t seem to be going in the direction that I wanted it to. I loved Amber, don’t get me wrong, but I’d recently wondered if she was truly the one for me. Quietly climbing out of bed, I was on my way to the bathroom when my cell phone beeped.

Knowing work was the only reason I’d get a text this early, I sighed and retrieved my phone from the dresser. Looking at the screen, I saw the text – Deceased teenager in Lakeview Park. Putting the phone back down, I walked out of the bedroom; stopping briefly to look at some photos I’d hung on the hallway wall.

They were your typical family photos; me with my parents doing various activities. Things like sitting in my Dad’s patrol car while pretending to drive, going trick or treating dressed as a cop, or on the football field after scoring the championship-winning touchdown. By looking at the smile on my face in all those photos, you’d think I was happy; but you’d be wrong.

You see my parents, especially my dad, were the type to exert absolute control over every aspect of my life growing up. It didn’t matter what I wanted to do; I had to do everything they told me. I wanted to join my school’s theater group, but my Dad insisted I do something more manly – so I reluctantly tried out for football. It didn’t matter that I was a decent football player, I still didn’t enjoy it that much.

The same thing happened when I graduated from High School; I wanted to go off to study economics, but my Dad pushed me into joining the police force. You see he’d been shot while serving a warrant as part of an investigation, forcing him to take an early retirement. My joining the force and becoming the youngest detective in department history was more about him wanting to relive his glory days through me then it was about honoring him.

I was about 5 minutes into my shower when I heard the door open, followed by Amber saying, “Let me guess, you got called into work?”

“Yeah,” rinsing some shampoo out of my eyes, I said, “they found a body in Lakeview Park.”

Poking her head through the shower curtain, Amber said, “I’m going out for a run; make sure you text me when you get there. Alright?”

It wasn’t until recently that Amber had started making that request; that I text her both when I got to work and when I was leaving. That was something I could live with; but I didn’t like that unless I had an errand to run, I had to come straight home after work.
Having succeeded in getting the shampoo from my eyes, I looked at her and said, “Sure thing, babe.”
1.title: Lying Awake In Bed

11.content:
There was a light drizzle as I drove through the main entrance to the park a scant 10 minutes from my apartment. Finding a spot across from the bathrooms, I noticed an ambulance and 3 patrol cars were already here. I briefly considered not sending Amber the text saying I’d arrived, only to remember what she’d do if I didn’t; she’d blow my phone up with calls until I answered.

After sending the text, I grabbed my jacket and stepped out of the car. I started towards the police tape only to be stopped when I saw my partner, Jamie Collins, approaching me. Handing me a cup of coffee, Jamie said, “How did your anniversary dinner go with Amber?”

“It went pretty much as I expected; except somehow she found a way to bring you into the conversation.”

Chuckling as he ducked under the tape, Jamie said, “I’ve been back in town for 3 months; you’d think she’d be used to us working together.”

“She’s slowly coming around on that.” Walking alongside Jamie, I said, “I just think it’ll take time for her to realize that our working relationship isn’t a continuation of our physical one.”

Now I know what you’re probably thinking; I swing both ways and Jamie used to be my boyfriend, but that couldn’t be farther from the truth. You see Jamie and I dated for almost 3 years in High School; but back then he was a girl named Emily. “Oh wow, why is she so hung up on that?”

Rounding the corner behind the bathroom, I said, “Relax, she’ll come around eventually; we just have to give her time."

“You got it, boss.” With a smile, Jamie said, “I’ll go speak with the witnesses, why don’t you go look at the crime scene.”

Walking further into the crime scene, I spotted the Medical Examiner kneeling by a nearby tree; it wasn’t until I got close that I saw the body leaning against the tree. The victim was a young woman, probably no older than 16 years old. There was blood on her jogging outfit and what appeared to be stab wounds on her chest and abdomen.

Walking up behind the coroner, I said, “I’m Detective Percy; what can you tell me?”

Looking at me, the coroner got to his feet and said, “Detective Percy; let me introduce to 15-year-old Chloe Hawkins.”

Jotting down that information on my notepad, I said, “Hawkins? As in Arthur Hawkins, the property mogul?”

Arthur Hawkins was a local businessman responsible for many of the commercial and residential developments in the area. He’d died of cancer about 4 years back. “That’s right Detective, Chloe was his granddaughter.”

Looking down at Chloe’s body, I said, “As I recall, there was speculation that she wasn’t actually related to Arthur.”

“Mr. Hawkins never married; so, when a young girl arrives in town claiming to be his granddaughter, everyone was right to be confused.” Wiping some dirt from his pants, the coroner said, “If memory serves, the day-to-day of the company was supposed to be handled by the Board until Chloe turned 18.”

I looked down at Chloe’s body, saddened to think that such a young life had been extinguished. Turning back to the coroner, I said, “What can I you tell me so far?”

“Well judging by the condition of the body, I’d estimate she was killed at some point within the last three hours.” Stepping closer to me, he said, “The wounds on her body are consistent with a bladed weapon, and I’ve noticed what appear to be several defensive wounds on her arms.”

I spoke with the Medical Examiner for a few minutes, getting his opinion about the case; everything I saw pointed towards an early morning mugging. After making sure to take some photos and ask that coroner keep me updated, I walked over to where Jamie was speaking with the witnesses. “I’m Detective Percy; did you two notice anything out of the ordinary prior to discovering the body?”

“N-No, we didn’t see anything unusual.” Barely keeping composure, the young woman said, “I was going to get a drink from the fountain when I discovered her body.”

I was about to respond when my phone started ringing; I groaned when I saw that it was Amber calling. Indicating to Jamie that I needed to take this, I stepped a short distance away before answering, “Now’s not an appropriate time, Amber; I’m in the middle of a case.”

“You forgot to text me, Andrew.” Her voice stern, Amber said, “Probably too busy cavorting with your ex, I bet?”

I looked upwards into the trees to keep my composure, “I’m really getting tired of repeating myself, Amber; there’s nothing going on between me and Jamie.” Pausing, I said, “Need I remind you that he has a girlfriend?”
11.title: Arriving at the Scene

111.content:
After returning to the station, I sent off yet another text to Amber before going to my desk. The conversation with Amber was still weighing heavily on my mind; enough to make me log into my OneDrive account and look at some old photos.

I spent the next 30 minutes going down memory lane; revisiting all 3 years of my relationship with Jamie before he realized he was trans. Prior to that realization, he was the epitome of femininity; cheer-squad captain, fashion trend-setter as well as Prom Queen. The two of us were inseparable and, at least for me, it felt like we were soul mates.

I was so focused on our Prom photo that I didn’t realize Jamie was standing behind me until he said, “I knew I was living a lie at that point; but that didn’t keep me from having a good time with you.” Taking a seat across from me, Jamie said, “I always thought of Prom as the last hurrah for that part of my life.”

“Sometimes I find myself thinking back to those days; how lucky I was to have a girlfriend who wasn’t the jealous type.” Checking to make sure the coast was clear, I looked at Jamie and said, “Do you ever wonder what things would’ve been like if we hadn’t broken up?”

With his characteristic doofy grin, Jamie said, “That would’ve required a major lifestyle change on your part, don’t you think?”
It took me a moment to realize what Jamie meant; but I smiled once I did, “That’s not what I meant, dummy.” Looking at Jamie, I said, “If you hadn’t realized you were trans, do you think we’d still be together?”

“I’m not sure, Andy; that’s not really something I think about.” Sighing, Jamie said, “But if it makes you feel better, we probably would still be together.”

Sensing this was an uncomfortable topic for him, I decided to change the subject, “Did the witnesses say anything else after I left?”

“Not really; based on what we know, I’m afraid the victim was already long dead before they even arrived in the park.”

*****************************


Jamie had left 10 minutes earlier; going to check up on another case we were working on. I was in the middle of finishing up my report when my phone began ringing. Picking it up, I said, “Homicide, Detective Percy.”

“Detective, this is Alistair Thorne from the Coroner’s office.”

Looking at the clock on my desk, I was surprised to see almost 2 hours had passed since my return to the office. I chuckled to myself, realizing that I’d been so laser focused on the report I lost all track of time. “Mr. Thorne, I assume you have some information for me?”

“How soon can you be at my office? I’ve discovered something rather interesting.”

The town’s emergency services were part of the same emergency complex, which was located a block away from town hall. This meant it was a quick 5-minute walk from my office to the Medical Examiner’s office. “Okay Mr. Thorne, what’s so interesting that you couldn’t tell me over the phone?”

Mr. Thorne silently led me into the exam room, where I saw Chloe’s body on the table. “As you know, it’s standard procedure to gather fingerprints and DNA from a victim.”

“Of course; that way we can make sure the victim is properly identified.” Confused, I said, “Did you find something interesting when you took that from Chloe?”

“Interesting doesn’t begin to describe it.” Stepping over to a computer, Mr. Thorne said, “Our victim isn’t Arthur Hawkins’ granddaughter.”

“What do you mean?” Looking at Mr. Thorne, I said, “Are you saying this is a case of mistaken identity?”

Looking back towards the body on the table, Mr. Thorne said, “I ran the test three times to make sure; but somehow this young girl is Arthur Hawkins.”

For a moment I thought perhaps Dr. Thorne had gone insane, “That’s impossible, Dr. Thorne; Arthur Hawkins was a 73-year-old man.” Leaning against the counter for support, I said, “How can that 15-year-old girl on the table possibly be him?”

“I can re-run the tests just be sure; but I doubt it will change the results.” Pausing, Dr. Thorne said, “Somehow, Arthur Hawkins found a way to turn himself into a teenage girl.”
111.title: Back at the Station

1111.content:
I had Dr. Thorne run the test again just to be sure, but the results were still the same. Even with the information staring me in the face, I still struggled to believe what I was seeing. With the printout in hand, I approached Chloe’s body. Her body was the textbook definition of a young girls with an attractive figure and slightly smaller than average breasts.

However, the printout in my hand was telling me this young girl was a 73-year-old man. Standing across from Dr. Thorne, with Chloe’s body between us, I said, “I’m still having a tough time processing this, so bear with me.” Looking at Dr. Thorne, I said, “Are you telling me that Arthur Hawkins underwent plastic surgery in order to appear as a teenage girl?”

“Yes and no; surgery was definitely involved, but it wasn’t to simply look like a teenage girl.” Retrieving some paperwork from his dead, Dr. Thorne said, “I know it sounds crazy; but that is a teenage girl lying on the slab, inside and out. I’m not sure she even knew it yet, but she was about 7 weeks pregnant.”

I took Anatomy in College, so I was easily able to recognize a complete female reproductive system on the images Dr. Thorne handed to me. “How does an old man, one who could barely walk I might add, turn himself into a girl so completely that she’s able to get pregnant?”

Taking the images back, Dr. Thorne said, “I’m just the coroner, I’m afraid; solving mysteries is your job.”

I stared at the body for a moment longer, “Forgetting about how this was done; what I want to know is why it was done.” Pausing for a moment, I said, “What could have possibly possessed Arthur Hawkins to do this?”

“I hope this doesn’t come off as me telling you how to do your job; but perhaps you should go to Ridgeview and search through Chloe’s personal effects.” Taking a seat at his desk, Dr. Thorne said, “Teenage girls are always confiding in each other; perhaps some of her classmates can shed a light on this for you.”

“That was going to be my next stop, Doc.” Heading to the door, I briefly turned around and said, “Do me a favor; try to figure out how someone could do something like this.”
1111.title: Processing What I Was Told

11111.content:
My Captain had the same look of utter confusion on his face that I did when I told him what Doctor Thorne had discovered. Sitting at his desk, Captain Jim Glover said, “You’re telling me that the 15-year-old girl we have in the morgue is actually a 73-year-old man?”

“Believe me sir, I’m still trying to process it myself; but that’s essentially it.” Taking a breath, I said, “And before you ask, Arthur didn’t simply undergo radical plastic surgery. He somehow turned himself into an anatomically correct 15-year-old.”

“I’ve seen some strange cases over the years, but nothing like this.” Sighing, Captain Glover said, “What is your plan of attack here?”

“With your permission I’d like to drive out to Ridgeview Academy and search the victim’s room; see if I can’t find anything to identify a possible suspect.”

“Don’t be surprised if you find Erica’s name on that list, Andrew.” Captain Glover’s face turned sour for a moment, “The deceased
was one of her more frequent tormentors.”

I’d known Erica Glover since she was born; thanks entirely to the fact that our fathers were old friends. I used to babysit for her in my younger years; but I hadn’t seen her for almost 3 years now. “Sir, I’m sure Erica had nothing to do with Ms. Hawkins’ death.”

****************************


Ridgeview Academy was a prestigious boarding school on the outskirts of town, catering to the children of local businessman and other wealthy individuals. It wasn’t the kind of school that I, a child of a blue-collar family, could afford to attend.

After driving through the gate onto the grounds, I parked outside the Administrative Building. I stopped myself before stepping out of the car, reminding myself to update Amber on my location. For a moment I considered not sending the text, but eventually she’d wonder where I was.

Getting out of the car after sending the text, I started to wonder if perhaps I should just break up with her. But then I realized if she was acting this way out of jealousy, she’d probably act 10x worse if I dumped her. I was so caught up in my train of thought that I wasn’t watching where I was going.

Before I could stop myself, I bumped into a young girl and caused her to fall down to the ground. Feeling terrible, I reached down to help her up, “I’m sorry about that, I wasn’t watching where I was I going.”

The girl didn’t even try to hide the fact that she was checking me out. Blushing a little bit as , she said, “It’s totally alright; I wasn’t watching where I was going either.”

I watched as the girl ran to catch up with two other girls; smiling when I heard one of them say, “He’s kind of cute.”

I stood at the bottom of the steps and watched as the girls walked around the corner. The longer I watched them, the more I envied them; they had their whole lives ahead of them.

I made my way inside the building and down the hall to the office. After announcing my presence, I sat down and waited for the Headmaster to come out. I got a text from Jamie while I was waiting – *I just spoke with Doc Thorne; I still can’t believe what he told me is true.*

*Tell me about it; I’m still trying to figure out why someone would do something like so drastic.*

The Headmaster’s door opened right after I sent off the reply to Jamie; a middle-aged woman stepping out. I was never a troublemaker in school, but the air of authority coming off her was enough to make me sit up straight.

Approaching me, she said, “Detective Percy; I’m Abigail Devereaux; Headmistress of Ridgeview Academy. What brings you here this fine morning?”

“I’d be more comfortable speaking in private, ma’am.”
11111.title: Talking with the Captain

111111.content:
As I watched the Headmistress react to the death of one of her students, it struck me how different she was from the instructors I’d had growing up. It was easy to see from the tears in her eyes that cared deeply about her students. If I had it to do over again, I thought, I wouldn't mind having her to teach me.

Wiping tears from her eyes, Headmistress Deveraux said, “Why would anyone want to kill such an innocent girl?”

“That’s what we’re trying to find out, ma’am.” Readjusting my position in the chair, I said, “To that end, I’d like your permission to search her room for any clues.”

Getting up from her desk and walking towards me, Headmistress Deveraux said, “Of course, if you think it will help identify who killed her.” Heading to the door, she said, “In the meantime, I’ll gather the students in the dining hall to tell them the unfortunate news.”

***************************


After getting both a key to Chloe’s room as well as directions, I left the Administrative Building and walked across campus to one of the 4 dorm buildings on the property. I noticed several students walking past me on their way to the dining hall; talking amongst themselves about what was going on.

Arriving outside Chloe’s room, I took a breath before stepping inside. The first thought entered my mind as I walked inside was that perhaps every test Dr. Thorne had run was wrong. Looking around the immaculate room, built for two, I could see that this was most certainly a girl’s room. Both closets were open and full of things like dresses and skirts; and probably two dozen pairs of shoes between them.

If the clothes and makeup in the bathroom weren’t enough, the pictures of the wall by Chloe’s bed were more than enough for me to doubt Dr. Thorne’s results. They included photos of her wearing a rather skimpy bikini on the beach, one of those ubiquitous group selfies with four other girls, in a cheer outfit and kissing a boy at some formal dance.

Damn, I thought as I looked at the photos closely, Arthur Hawkins definitely wasn’t one for half measures.

I was photographing everything when my phone started to ring; digging it from my pocket, thinking that it was Amber calling, I was relieved to see it was only Jamie. Putting an earbud in my ear, I answered the call, “Hey Jamie.”

“Have you found anything of interest at the school?”

“Not yet; I’ve only been in Chloe’s room for a few minutes.” Looking around the room once more, I said, “I’m still no closer to figuring out how Chloe managed to become a girl; but she was really committed to being a teenage girl. I mean, she’s got more dresses and shoes then you did.”

"Sounds like she would've given me a run for my money." Chuckling, Jamie said, "I never saw it as a problem but mom would always say half the stores in the mall were in business because of me."

“I’m afraid I have to side with your Mom, Jamie; I remember one time you dragged me from store to store buying every outfit you could get your hands on.” Leaning against the wall, I said, “I mean why spend close to $1000 on clothes only to announce a few months later that you want to transition.”

"Come on Andy, you know what it's like being a teenager." With a sigh, Jamie continued, "I was being pulled in every possible direction; part of me wasn't sure if I was just conflicted or if this was real."

Closing my eyes for a moment, I said, "I know, Jamie; you forget I was there with you every step of the way."

"I know, and I can never repay you for that; you were an incredibly supportive boyfriend."

Jamie and I continued along that line of conversation for a few more minutes, until I noticed something on Chloe’s desk. Pulling it out, I saw that it was a letter from some company called Ovid. “Jamie, have you ever heard of Ovid?”

“No, can’t say as I have. Why?”

I quickly perused the letter; something about there being a data breach and certain information may have been compromised.
“There’s a letter from them on Chloe’s desk; something about a breach and information being compromised.”

There was a brief pause before Jamie responded, “What if this company was the one responsible for turning Arthur into Chloe?”

“If that’s true; then what if whoever hacked their system discovered Chloe’s true identity.” Taking a photo of the letter, I said, “We could be dealing with a blackmail situation here, Jamie; someone wanted money from Chloe and killed her when she wouldn’t do it.”

“Send me a copy of the letter, I’ll do some research on the company when I get back to the station.” Pausing, Jamie said, “Let me know if you find anything else of interest.”

The call ended just as I heard someone fumbling with the door. After a moment, the door opened and a teenage girl of Italian descent entered the room. Judging from the messed-up makeup on her face, she’d been crying recently. She stopped in her tracks once she saw me, no doubt thinking I was some weirdo breaking into her room. “W-Who are you?”

“I’m Detective Percy with the Lakeview Police Department; I’m here investigating Chloe Hawkins' murder.” Pausing, trying my best to sound gentle, I said, “Are you her roommate?”

“Y-Yeah, I’m her roommate.” Wiping tears from her eyes, the girl said, “I’m Josie Russo.”
111111.title: Speaking to the Headmistress

1111111.content:
The first ten minutes of my conversation with Josie Russo were spent sitting on the bed as she cried. I knew she was grieving over the loss of her friend and roommate, and I wanted to be sympathetic, but I did have an investigation to run. “I’m terribly sorry for your loss, Miss Russo,” finally speaking up, I said, “but I’d like to ask you some questions if I may.”

"Sorry," she said, wiping the tears from her eyes. "I guess I must seem like a bum trip."

Chuckling, I said, “Sorry; but isn’t that a little out of date for a modern teenager."

Josie reacted as if I'd caught her with her hand in the cookie jar. “I guess it’s something I picked up from my grandfather.”

Looking towards her nightstand, I saw a photo of her with an older man – who I assumed was her grandfather. I quickly recognized him as Marcus Russo, a one-term governor and former friend of my grandfather. I didn’t know all the details, but something had happened to drove a wedge between them. I even remembered him coming to my school once for an assembly. “Marcus Russo was your grandfather?”

“Poppa took me in after my parents died; he raised me on his own for 5 years until a heart attack took him.”

I remembered hearing that story on that news; my Grandfather had even considered reaching out. “I remember the car accident, but I don’t recall anything about him having a granddaughter.”

“You can blame Poppa for that; he thought he’d lose support if it became known his daughter had a child out of wedlock.”
Reaching for some tissues, Josie said “I didn’t even know he existed until he introduced himself at the funeral.”

Taking my notepad out, I said, “Now back to the case: Did Chloe Hawkins have any enemies here?"

Lying back on her bed, Josie said, “Just Darcy Hawthorne."

Making note of the name, I said, “Would you care to elaborate? "

“Darcy had this on-again/off-again relationship with this guy, Colin; during one of their off-again phases, Chloe swooped in and nabbed him for herself.” Looking at me, Josie said, “I’m not saying Darcy killed her; but she’s the closest thing Chloe had to an enemy here.”

I made sure to write down both Darcy and Colin’s names, reminding myself to speak with them. It seemed likely that Colin was the father of Chloe’s unborn child; news of which might have pushed Darcy over the edge.

The question continued for another few minutes until there was a knock at the door. After getting my permission to answer it, Josie got up and opened the door. I leaned forward just enough to see _______.
1111111.title: Talking with Josie

11111111.content:
I watched as several of Josie’s classmates, four girls and three boys, walked into the room. Having 9 people inside the already cramped room was enough to give me anxiety. As the group took seats where they could, I recognized one of the girls as the one who’d said I was cute.

I watched as all seven of them, starting with an athletically built blonde, each gave Josie hugs. Once that was finished, Josie gestured to me and said, “This is Detective Percy; he’s investigating Chloe’s murder.”

Looking at the group, I said, “I take it you all knew Chloe?”

A tall boy, whose red hair and green eyes hinted at his Irish heritage, nodded, “Our classmates all called us the Legacies; because we’ve all inherited fortunes from relatives.”

“I’m terribly sorry for your loss; I’ll be back over the coming days to speak with each of you in private.” Handing them some business cards, I said, “If any of you thinks of something, please don’t hesitate to call me.”

After leaving the dorm building, I decided to take a short break to collect my thoughts. Spotting a bench overlooking the lake, I figured that was as good a place as any. I took a seat as a flock of ducks swam by. These are lucky kids, I thought. What I wouldn't give to be able to start my life all over again, wherever I wanted.

I was so deep in thought that I didn’t realize there was someone standing behind me until I heard them clear their throat. Turning around, I saw _____.
11111111.title: Meeting Josie's Classmates

111111112.content:
Seeing Headmistress Devereaux standing there, I said, “Ms. Devereaux, can I help you?”

“I was coming to ask you that same question, Detective.” Taking a seat next to me, she said, “I could tell during our conversation that you were preoccupied with something; and I’m fairly certain it wasn’t Ms. Hawkins’ untimely death.”

I was once again taken aback by the surprising amount of compassion Ms. Deveraux appeared to have for her students. The fact that I, someone who was almost 5 years older than her oldest students, was being given the same level of compassion was astounding. Looking at her, I said, “You ever find yourself thinking about some important life decision, and regretting the choice you made?”

“I think everyone has had moments like that in their lives; it’s completely normal to have regrets.” Turning towards the lake as she sighed, Headmistress Devereaux continued, “What is it that has you so preoccupied, Detective?”

Looking out over the lake, I said, “I’ve had absolutely no say in my life for the last few years; my parents and even my girlfriend run my life.” Sighing, I said, “I joined the football team and became a cop because that’s what my father wanted, I can’t hang out with my co-workers because of my girlfriend’s preoccupation with my partner.”

There was something about the Headmistress that made it hard for me to read her. Looking at me, she said, “Sometimes parents feel the need to live vicariously through their children; was your father a cop as well?”

“Yeah; for 25 years until he was shot by someone holding up a convenience store.” Sighing, I said, “Here’s the kicker; he wasn’t
even on duty at the time.”

“That explains your father then; but your girlfriend is still a mystery.” Taking a brief pause, she said, “Why is she so preoccupied with your partner?”

“Because my partner and I dated throughout most of High School; Amber seems convinced that we’re somehow continuing our relationship.”

“I suppose I can understand a little of where she’s coming from; especially if her boyfriend spends every day with his ex-girlfriend.” Sighing, she said, “Have the two of you done anything to alleviate her concerns?”

I knew enough not to divulge Jamie’s private life to a stranger, but I felt the need to explain the situation. “I’ve done everything I can to explain the situation to Amber; I still care about my partner but not in the romantic way that I used to.”

“If I were in your position, I would sit down with Amber and your ex; the three of you need to have a frank conversation about this.”

Fidgeting with my keys, I said, “Easier said than done; neither of them really likes being in the same room with each other. My ex thinks Amber is being too controlling, while Amber...well, you know.”

Headmistress Devereaux and I spoke for a few more minutes until I figured it was time to leave. As I got up from the bench, she said, “I’m guessing this probably won’t be the last time I see you here?”

“No ma’am, I’ll be back to speak with the rest of Chloe’s friends, plus two persons of interest.” Reaching out my hand, I said,
“Thank you for taking the time to check on me; your students are lucky to have someone like you looking out for them.”

“You’re welcome, Detective.” Shaking my hand, Headmistress Devereaux said, “I hope you’re able to find answers to your questions; both with the case and your personal life.”
111111112.title: A Caring Headmistress

1111111121.content:
I updated Amber on my location as I stepped out of the elevator and walked down the hall. Entering the room, I saw Jamie focused on his computer screen with ear buds in his ears. Sneaking up behind him, I shook his chair and laughed as he lurched forward. Spotting me, he pulled out an earbud, “Dammit Andy, you know I hate it when you do that!”

“You know what your problem is, Jamie?” Seeing the angry look on Jamie’s face as I sat at my desk, I said, “You become hyper-focused on one specific task; you’d never be able to sneak up on my like that.”

“Yeah, well your problem is that you do shit like that when you should be focused on something else.”

Jamie’s anger, and the look on his face, gave me pause – as I remembered having similar arguments when we were dating.
“Sorry, it’s just how I relieve stress.” Turning my computer, I said, “Were you able to find anything on Ovid?”

Jamie started to calm down as he looked at me, “I haven’t been able to find anything on Ovid; it’s like the company doesn’t exist.” Gesturing for me come behind him, Jamie said, “The only clue I’ve found to their existence came from that letter you sent me; the address came back to a business park about an hour from here.”

The gears turning in my head, I said, “Are you feeling up for a drive?”

“Sure, why not.” Grabbing his jacket, Jamie said, “You can fill me in on the way.”

**************************************


Because of the state Josie had been in, I didn’t have much to give Jamie during the ride up. “I’m going back tomorrow to interview the rest of Chloe’s friends; in hindsight it probably wasn’t smart to question them so soon after learning of their friend’s death.” Sighing as I went down the off-ramp, I said, “Everyone I spoke to, including the Headmistress, said Chloe was a model student and generally well liked. They couldn’t believe anyone would kill her.”

Looking over my notes, Jamie said, “What about this Darcy girl?”

“I did a search while you were in the bathroom; the only offenses on her record were some minor shoplifting charges from a few years ago.” Glancing at Jamie, I said, “Besides, I really don’t think she’d kill Chloe solely because she stole her boyfriend.”

“Speaking from experience, I can tell you that girls can become irrational when it becomes to relationships.” Blushing, Jamie said, “You remember how jealous I got when I saw you hanging out with that girl in 10th grade?”

With a chuckle, I said, “How could I forget? You would’ve broken her nose had I not said she was my cousin.”

“Well sorry; she was awfully clingy.” Sighing, Jamie said, “Getting back to my point; don’t discount her or the boyfriend just yet.”

Spotting the sign for the business park down the road, I said, “We’re here.”

As we pulled into a parking spot, Jamie said, “Considering how hard it is to find information about these people, I doubt they’ll be happy when two detectives walk in unannounced.”

Getting out of the car, I said, “We’ll be delicate then.”

Walking into the building, we found the suite on the directory and took the elevator to the 5th floor. Entering the suite, I saw that it was rather spartan – only a few chairs and a table. There was a receptionist window nearby along with another door. The receptionist, a woman a few years older than us, eyed us suspiciously. “Can I help you gentlemen?”

“We’re Detectives Percy and Collins with the Lakeview Police Department.” Pausing, I said, “We’re investigating a murder and your company was brought to our attention. We’d like to speak with whoever’s in charge.”

Looking at us for a moment, the girl said...
1111111121.title: Back at the Station

11111111211.content:
The drive was going smoothly until about 20 minutes from our destination, when the oil pressure light on my dash suddenly came on. Pulling off into a rest stop, I opened the hood as Jamie got out of the car. As he reached for the dipstick, Jamie took one look at it before turning to me, “Geez Andy, when was the last time you added any oil to the car?”

Thinking to myself for a moment, I said, “It’s been a while; guess I’ve just had a lot on my mind.”

Coming around to the driver’s side, Jamie reached inside and opened the trunk, “Why don’t you go get us some sandwiches or something, I’ll put some oil in the car and check the rest of the fluids.”

There was a line of people waiting to make their orders at the Subway inside the building, so by the time I got back outside Jamie was all finished with the car. The two of us walked over to a bench and sat down. Looking at him, I said, “Thanks for helping with the car, man; I still know next to nothing about general car maintenance.”

“Trust me, I know.” Chuckling as he took a bite of his grinder, Jamie said, “There aren’t many guys who ask their girlfriends for help when their car won’t start; on the way to Homecoming, I might add.”

I groaned, “You’re never going to let me live that down, are you?”

“You had me looking inside the hood of your car, while I was wearing a $400 dress.” Grinning, Jamie said, “You’re just lucky I didn’t get it dirty.”

“Well like I said back then, I appreciate the help.”

The two of us ate in silence for a while, until Jamie looked at me and said, “So when are you going to tell me what’s on your mind?”

Turning to Jamie, I said, “What do you mean?”

“I’ve known you for close to 15 years, Andy; I know when something’s bothering you.” Placing the sandwich on the bench between us, Jamie said, “So what’s on your mind?”

Realizing there was no way out of this, I said, “With everything going on with my Dad and Amber lately, it feels like my life is spinning out of control.” Sighing, I said, “My mom tries her best to help, but you’re the only one who really seems willing to let me live my life how I want to.”

Jamie had a peculiar look on his face as he looked at me, “I can’t say as I blame you; your dad’s been controlling pretty much every aspect of your life since I’ve known you. And Amber, well she’s just being a controlling bitch.” Sighing, he said, “If you ask me; what you need to do is change something significant about your life. Only once you’ve done that will you be happy.”

“It’s funny you say that, because the Headmistress said something similar to me.” Looking up at the sky, I said, “She explained to me how a lot of her students didn’t discover who they really were until they arrived at that school.”

Placing a hand on my shoulder, Jamie said, “I’m here for you, Andy; if you ever need support or a shoulder to cry on.”

“Thanks Jamie.” Grabbing the rest of my sandwich, I said, “What do you say we get going?”

“Sounds like a plan to me; I’ve got dinner plans with Jessica tonight.”

My phone beeped as we walked back to the car; as I took it from my pocket, I saw it was a text from the station. Catching up to Jamie, I said, “Hannah just did a preliminary search for information on those possible suspects; the girl, Darcy, has some minor shoplifting charges and the boyfriend’s clean as a whistle.”

As we got back in the car, Jamie said, “That doesn’t entirely rule them out though; having her boyfriend stolen could have thrown Darcy over the edge, and what if the boyfriend discovered the truth about Chloe? I’d be pretty upset if my girlfriend turned out to be a man in his 70s.”

Turning the car on, I said, “They’ll be the first ones I speak to when I go back to the school tomorrow. After that I’ll finish speaking with Chloe’s friends.”

We got to the business park a short time later. Pulling into a parking spot, Jamie said, “Considering how hard it was to find information about these people, I doubt they’ll be happy to see two detectives walk.”

Getting out of the car, I said, “We’ll be delicate then.”

Walking into the building, we found the suite on the directory and took the elevator to the 5th floor. Entering the suite, I saw that it was rather spartan – only a few chairs and a table. There was a receptionist window nearby along with another door. The receptionist, a woman a few years older than us, eyed us suspiciously. “Can I help you gentlemen?”

“We’re Detectives Percy and Collins with the Lakeview Police Department.” Pausing, I said, “We’re investigating a murder and your company was brought to our attention. We’d like to speak with whoever’s in charge.”
11111111211.title: The Drive Up

111111112111.content:
It wound up being that we waited for almost an hour before someone finally came to speak with us. I’d never been one to sit around; so, when you add in the fact that we were investigating a murder, I was rather annoyed.

Jamie had gone off to use the bathroom and I was fiddling with something on my phone when the door opened. Looking up, I saw a man step out wearing a business suit. Getting a good look at him, I figured he was probably only a few years older than me. Walking up to me, he said, “I’m sorry for the wait, Detective; I’m Jonathan Crane, Regional Manager.”

As Jamie re-entered the room, I said, “Mr. Crane, we’re here on police business and you kept us waiting for almost an hour.” Sighing, I continued, “Some might consider that to be obstruction.”

“I’m sorry; but our clients pay handsomely for our services and expect there to be some discretion.” Gesturing towards the door, Mr. Crane said, “So when two men stop by unannounced and claim to be police officers, we have to be careful.”

Heading towards the door, Jamie said, “I assume you were simply trying to confirm we were telling the truth?”

Mr. Crane silently nodded as he followed us through the door, “Your Captain was rather tightlipped, so I’m hoping you’ll be more forthcoming about why you’re here?”

Jamie and I stared at each other as we followed Mr. Crane down the hall. Once we entered a conference room the two of us sat down while Mr. Crane closed the door. As he took a seat across from us, I said, “Your company came up during a murder investigation.” Pulling up photos of Chloe on my phone, I slid the phone towards Mr. Crane, “The victim was Chloe Hawkins, a 15-year-old student at Ridgeview Academy. There was a letter addressed to her about some personal information being stolen.”

Jamie and I quickly took note of the color draining from Mr. Crane’s face; so much so that Jamie said, “Do you recognize her, Mr. Crane?”

Composing himself, Mr. Crane slid the phone back to me, “No, I can’t say that I do; as our services aren’t offered to clients under the age of 18.”

After casting a quick glance at me, Jamie turned to Mr. Crane and said, “What services does your company offer?”

“Our company designs and sells high-end forms of entertainment for our clientele; things such as virtual reality and the like.” Pausing, beginning to look a little concerned, Mr. Crane continued, “I’m sure you’ll understand that our clients use our services for reasons they’d prefer to be kept from the public.”

Jamie and I stared at each other again, it was becoming clear that Mr. Crane wasn’t going to be forthcoming with us. Turning my attention back to him, I said, “It’s not wise to lie during a police investigation, Mr. Crane.”

“I assure you, Detective, I’ve been nothing but truthful to you.”

“There you go again with the lying, Mr. Crane.” Retrieving my phone once more, I pulled up some more information. Handing in back to him, I said, “We have incontrovertible proof that Chloe Hawkins isn’t Arthur Hawkins’ granddaughter; she was Arthur Hawkins.”
111111112111.title: Meeting the Representative

1111111121111.content:
Mr. Crane became more forthcoming once I revealed that bombshell. Still shocked, he looked at me and said, “How could you possibly know that?”

“Mr. Hawkins spent the evening in our drunk tank a few years ago; the fingerprints from that incident matched those taken from Ms. Hawkins.” Gesturing to Jamie as I leaned forward, I said, “Perhaps you’d like to explain how a 73-year-old man turns himself in a fully-functional 15-year-old girl?”

Letting out an exasperated sigh, Mr. Crane said, “I’m afraid the explanation for how is out of my league, but I can explain to you the why.” Leaning forward, Mr. Crane said, “To put it in the simplest terms possible; Mr. Crane was dying, and he wanted another turn on the merry-go-round.”

Glancing at me, Jamie said, “I guess I can’t fault someone for wanting a second chance; but why change genders to do it?” taking a pause, Jamie said, “It seems to me like simply becoming young again would have been the easiest thing to do.”

“I can’t speak for Mr. Hawkins; but there are many people, myself included, who sometimes wonder what it would be like as the opposite gender.” Pausing, Mr. Crane said, “Perhaps Mr. Hawkins wanted to spend this second time around as a girl.”

Jamie and I listened intently for the next 20 minutes or so as Mr. Crane further explained the company’s arrangement with Mr. Hawkins. That arrangement involved creating a cover story to explain the sudden appearance of a hitherto unknown granddaughter, followed by a delicate procedure to transform him into that granddaughter. Looking at Mr. Crane, Jamie said, “So I’m guessing the plan was for Ms. Hawkins to receive her inheritance once she turned 18?”

“That’s right, Detective Collins; upon reaching her 18th birthday, Chloe Hawkins would have been a rather wealthy young woman.” Frowning, Mr. Crane said, “I can’t fathom why someone would want to kill her.”

Jamie gave me a look that told me it was my turn to speak up, “Even if we disregard her inheritance for the time being, there’s still several other possible motives: jealously and her pending motherhood.”

I watched the color drain from Mr. Crane’s face once more, “Ms. Hawkins was pregnant?”

With a nod, I said, “The Medical Examiner determined that she was somewhere between 6 to 8 weeks along; we’re not even certain she was aware of it.” Taking a breath, I said, “I went to the school earlier and spoke with her roommate, who told me Chloe had recently become involved with an older classmate. It seems this boy’s ex was the jealous type; she wasn’t very happy to learn that Chloe was seeing her ex, she may have lashed out if she learned of the pregnancy.”

***********************


The conversation revolved around discussing possible motives for Chloe’s murder; as I was uncomfortable discussing police matters, I decided to steer the conversation in another direction. “Forgive me, Mr. Crane; perhaps you can tell us the nature of this hack?”

Taking a deep breath to compose himself, Mr. Crane said, “Our servers were breached just over a month ago; six of our clients had their information stolen, Ms. Hawkins being one of them.” Sighing, Mr. Crane continued, “While we didn’t reveal the nature of the stolen information, we did inform the proper authorities of the breach.”

Turning to Jamie, I said, “Does any of this make sense to you? Someone goes through all this trouble to hack some secure servers and only steals the information on six people?” taking a pause, I said, “With the nature of the information, you’d think everyone’s information would have been compromised.”

Mr. Crane spoke up before Jamie could respond, “I’m afraid it gets even stranger, Detective; all six individuals are students at Ridgeview Academy.”

To say I hadn’t expected that revelation would be an understatement. Looking at Mr. Crane, I said, “Are you telling me that there are five more people like Chloe attending Ridgeview?”

“It’s possible there could be even more than that; I was only told about the clients whose information had been compromised.”
Checking his watch, Mr. Crane said, “I have another meeting to attend; if you gentlemen want, I can have Ms. Hawkins file sent over.”

Casting a look towards Jamie, I said, “Sure, that would be appreciated; it might give us some insight into who killed her.” Getting up, I said, “Would it be possible for us to get the information regarding the breach as well?”

“I don’t see why not; but it will have to be heavily redacted.” Walking towards the door, Mr. Crane said, “I understand you’re just doing your jobs, but I still have to protect our client’s privacy.”

After leading us back to the reception area, Mr. Crane said goodbye before walking away. As we left the building, Jamie turned to me, “What’s on your mind, Andy?”

“I’m just thinking about what Crane said, how there’s at least five other clients attending that school.” Getting into the car, I continued, “It boggles the mind that some of the students I saw could actually be older than us.”

Looking at his phone as he climbed into the car, Jamie said, “We’ll leave that for tomorrow; our shift will be over by time we get back to the station.”
1111111121111.title: Mr. Crane Comes Clean

11111111211111.content:
After dropping Jamie off at the station, I grabbed my phone to text Amber only to find that it was dead. That revelation came as a surprise to me, as I was certain I’d plugged it into the charger before we left Ovid. Crap, I thought to myself, Amber’s going to kill me.

Once I’d made sure that the charger was plugged in, I drove out of the parking lot certain that I was going to get an earful when I got home. I turned my phone on a few minutes away from the apartment and, sure enough, I was quickly bombarded by an assortment of angry texts and voicemails – all from Amber.

Choosing to ignore them, I pulled into my reserved spot in the parking lot and walked upstairs. Amber must’ve seen me pulling into the parking lot, because I founder her angrily glaring at me the moment I stepped through the door. I barely had a chance to acknowledge the fact she was wearing a fancy dress before she started yelling at me, “Where the hell have you been, Andrew?
You know you’re supposed to let me know where you are every hour.”

Geez, I bet the students at Ridgeview don’t have to deal with rules like this. Closing the door so the neighbors wouldn’t hear the argument, I said, “I’m sorry Amber; my phone died, and I guess I forgot to charge it.”

“Oh please, do you really expect me to believe that?” crossing her arms, Amber exclaimed, “You were probably off screwing around with that partner of yours, weren’t you.”

I was getting fed up with Amber’s constant insinuations that there was something going on between me and Jamie. “How many times do I have to say this before you finally believe me? There is nothing sexual going on between me and Jamie.” Sighing, I said, “If there were, that would involve a pretty drastic change in lifestyle for me; and we certainly wouldn’t be dating.”

“Please; it’s not a stretch to think that you two aren’t doing anything, I mean you slept with him how many times during High School?”

“That was before either of us realized who Jamie really was; our physical relationship stopped almost immediately after he came out.” Attempting to change the subject, I said, “If you’re done throwing baseless accusations at me, perhaps you can explain why you’re dressed like that?”

“You’d know if you bothered to check your phone; your parents invited us to dinner, and I told them we’d be there.” Gesturing towards the bedroom, Amber said, “I left some clothes on the bed for you; shower and get dressed, we’re meeting them in 45 minutes.”

Great, I thought to myself as I walked into the bedroom, not only do I have to contend with an angry girlfriend; now I’m forced to deal with my controlling father.
11111111211111.title: Trouble at Home

111111112111111.content:
Much to my immense displeasure, my argument with Amber continued during the ride to the restaurant. It got to the point where, in the heat of the moment, I said something I shouldn’t have. “I can’t believe how hypocritical you’re being, Amber.” Looking at her, I continued, “It’s not okay for me to work with my ex, but it’s okay for you to have lunch with yours?”

Looking at me with a glare in her eyes, Amber said, “That’s completely different; we were just meeting to catch up. In case you’ve forgotten, he’s married, and his wife is pregnant.”

“Oh, I’m sorry, I guess that makes it perfectly fine then.” Getting angry, I said, “Need I remind you; Jamie has a girlfriend of his own. By the way, she doesn’t get upset about him working with me.”

That silenced Amber for the rest of the drive; something I was immensely thankful for. As we arrived at the restaurant, I caught sight of my parents waiting outside the entrance. As I parked the car, Amber turned to me and said, “I’d rather we didn’t argue in front of your parents.”

Getting out of the car, my voice dripping with sarcasm, I said, “Heaven forbid they hear us arguing; it’s not like they don’t already know Jamie is a hot topic for you.” Sighing, I said, “I hate to break it to you; but neither of them understands why you’re so hung up on this.”

Walking to catch up to me, Amber said, “I doubt that very much; your fathers told me several times that he thinks Jamie is more of a man then you are.” Glaring at me, she continued, “That must be a blow to your manhood; knowing your father thinks your ex is more masculine then you.”

I chose to ignore that comment; not because I didn’t believe it, but because I didn’t want to have a public fight with my girlfriend. After greeting my parents, the four of us went inside and got seated in the main dining room. Once our drinks orders had been taken, my Dad looked at me and said, “So Andrew, I understand you’re working a particularly interesting case?”

I wasn’t surprised to learn Dad had heard of the case; he still had friends in the Department who were likely keeping tabs on me. I could only hope that he didn’t know the shocking truth about Chloe. “Yeah; this teenage girl was found stabbed multiple times in Lakeview Park. The autopsy showed she was probably less than 2 months pregnant at time of death.”

“Do you have any suspects?”

I hated talking shop with Dad; because he’d always try to but in and give me some advice. Sometimes his advice was helpful, like when I was investigating what I thought was a murder-suicide a few months back; but he didn’t know all the facts this time around. “I went up to the victim’s school; her roommate told me about two possible suspects – the boyfriend, and potential father, as well as the boyfriend’s ex.”

That conversation went up for a little while, until Dad said, “I’ve heard good things about your work, Andrew; there’s even rumors of you getting a promotion soon.”

Great, I thought, a promotion in a career that I didn’t want in the first place. Our drinks had arrived at that point, so I took a sip of my Coke and turned to face my Dad, “I’ve been thinking, Dad; perhaps I’ll take some time off after this case is finished, to rethink my career choices.”

“There’s no need for that, Andrew; you’ve got a bright future where you are.” Sighing, Dad said, “You’re a detective, and you’ll stay that way until you’re promoted even further.”

I thought back to the kids at Ridgeview; how they were able to make decisions on their own without parental guidance. In that moment, I wanted nothing more than to have that ability. “But Dad...”

“No buts, son; you’ve got yourself a fine career helping the people of this town.” Sighing, Dad said, “I refuse to let any son of my waste his life in something like finance.”

I could hear the derision in Dad’s tone as he mentioned finance. Finances was something I had an innate knack for; in High School, thanks to some good investments, I was the only one in my class who had enough money to buy the Xbox One the day it came out. Looking at Dad, I said, “I get that you’re trying to help me, Dad; but this is my life. Only I should decide what I want to do with it.”

Rather than wait for the argument that I knew was coming, I got up and walked out of the restaurant – leaving my parents and Amber staring after me as I left. I barely made it to my car before I heard footsteps behind me; turning around I was relieved to see that it was my Mom. Catching up to me, she said, “Please don’t do this, Andrew; your father is simply trying to help you.”

“No he’s not, Mom; he’s just being a controlling ass.” Unlocking my car door, I said, “He pushed me into being a detective simply so he could relive his glory days before he got shot.”

I knew from the look on her face that Mom knew I was right; as Dad was controlling of her as well. “Where are you going, Andrew?”

As my phone started ringing, I said, “I don’t know, Mom; I just need to clear my head.”

After hugging Mom, I got in the car and drove out of the parking lot; ignoring the dozens of angry texts I was receiving from Amber. Sitting at the intersection, I figured I could grab some things from the apartment before Amber got home; after that I could get a hotel room or spend the night at Jamie’s.
111111112111111.title: Dinner with My Parents

info.brief_description: A murder investigation leads to surprising changes for a young police detective.
info.description:
Andrew Percy is a 22 year old detective with the Lakeview Police Department; one morning he's called to investigate the untimely death of a 15 year old girl - the granddaughter of a well-known local businessman. Everything about the case seems pretty straightforward, until it's discovered that the 15 year old granddaughter is actually the businessman himself.

Andrew Percy must now go undercover at the victim's school to uncover the reason why she was murdered. In order to do this, Andrew must turn himself into a 14 year old girl.

While endeavoring to complete his assignment, Andrew begins to discover things about himself.

Rules:
1. Use proper grammar
2. No descriptive sex scenes (keep it PG)
3. Be creative with storylines but keep close to the original idea.
4. Use the 1st person perspective (I, I'm, I'll, etc) - keep it from Andrew's POV

There will be an outline of the characters.
